content.rendered:
Container Port 4.0TM

We envision in the 4th industrial age, an intelligent container port enabled by smart real-time connectivity and embedded within the larger supply chain, driving synchronised coordination among all stakeholders. Container Port 4.0TM (CP4.0TM) is PSA’s technology blueprint and vision for our Container Port of the Future.

We invite you to co-create this future container port with PSA unboXed.

Connected Community

Ports are an integral component of an extensive global supply chain which comprises of other members such as shipping lines, forwarders, third-party logistics (3PL), warehouses and truckers. By being more connected electronically and working more collaboratively, the supply chain can be made more efficient, agile and scalable.

  • Collaborative workflow and streamlined digital documentation for vessel stowage planning, freight arrangement, trade financing and compliance, and supply chain execution to reduce iterative processes.
  • Real-time end-to-end freight and supply chain visibility, secured by access control and cybersecurity, to all stakeholders instead of relayed dissemination down the chain, enabling flexible and dynamic scheduling.
  • Crowd-sourcing and asset-sharing business solutions to improve asset utilisation and service scalability.
  • Use of Big Data, Analytics and Artificial Intelligence for predictive and seamless supply chain events, synchronizing freight movement in a way that reduces inventory costs.
  • Marketplaces to expand procurement options for supply chain services.
  • Integration within port communities of the various activities and transactions among actors such as authorities, customs, pilots, tugs, shipping agents and service providers to achieve better coordination.

Machine Augmented Workforce

Existing business workflow processes may be manual and tedious. To increase service delivery and quality, enterprise technology solutions that tap on Artificial Intelligence (AI), Robotic Process Automation (RPA) and integrated application software will free up capabilities in a skilled workforce.

  • Harnessing Big Data, Analytics and AI for key enterprise processes such as intelligence gathering, recruitment and onboarding.
  • RPA for clerical and repetitive administrative processes including report writing, data extraction and server administration, as well as finance processes such as reconciliations and AR/AP processing.
  • Enterprise data and resource management.

Automated Container Handling

Port operations involve human interaction with heavy machinery – it is manual and has significant health and safety considerations. To improve the safety, productivity and well-being of port workers, we see machine-assisted solutions as the future.

  • Solutions that improve the safety and user experience of all man-machine interfaces.
  • Machine-assisted coning/deconing operations and lashing solutions to enhance the safety and productivity of the stevedores.
  • Autonomous cargo handling machines relying on markerless navigation systems that are able to operate in inclement weather and able to effect swift, automatic and precise hand-offs between equipment.
  • Smart fleet management systems for automatic vehicles or truck platooning solutions for horizontal transfer of cargo.
  • Contactless or near-contactless solutions for power transmission to heavy container handling equipment and refrigerated containers.

Smart Engineering

Machines, equipment and systems that are able to sense, respond and enable the execution of new capabilities.

  • Sensor-equipped autonomous machines that are able to survey port and marine equipment (such as cranes) and infrastructure (such as underdeck marine structures) that are relatively inaccessible to humans for maintenance and fault detection.
  • Holistic maintenance solutions for port equipment enabled by Internet of Things (IoT) solutions, predictive analytics, job scheduling and supply of parts.
  • Smart inventory management solutions for spares and parts including innovative storage, warehouse AGVs, supply solutions and 3D printing.
  • Remote, virtual, augmented reality or telepresence applications in areas such as training, supervisor-assisted maintenance and operations management.

Orchestrated Operations

A huge amount of data is generated on a daily basis from port operations equipment, such as cranes and trucks, and systems such as planning systems and public sources. With data analytics, machine learning, A.I. and simulation, this data can be harnessed to achieve consistent and sustained high productivity, asset utilisation and customer service levels through data-driven decisions.

  • Internet of Things (IoT) solutions for machine learning enabled, data driven optimisation.
  • Coordinated execution of land and ship-side operations to facilitate intermodal cargo flow and connections upon vessel’s arrival and berthing to gate-out and vice versa.
  • Harnessing big data for the synchronization of hinterland cargo movement.
  • Integrated multi-channel communications.
  • Data analytics that lead to actionable business and operational outcomes.

Pre-emptive Health, Safety and Security

Health, Safety and Security risks in ports will be addressed pre-emptively or in real time by infusing surveillance systems with video and data analytics, and machine-triggered responses.

  • Systems, sensors and wearables that are able to address Health, Safety and Security issues in an integrated manner in real time.
  • Surveillance system using a whole range of sensors with advance analytics capability to automatically detect, respond to, and review abnormal and potentially dangerous situations involving human and physical wp-content.
  • Apps that promote Health, Safety and Security among individuals through social interaction and gamification.
  • Geofencing solutions utilising contactless verification of moving wp-content and intruder detection in controlled access zones, integrated in workflow processes.
  • Location tracking of personnel and equipment in the port in real time.

Sustainable Environment

Solutions within a port that actively manage energy consumption, generate and regenerate energy, recycle materials and consumables, and reduce emissions.

  • Electrification of port equipment, including cranes and vehicles for horizontal transfer of cargo, with efficient battery charging and management.
  • Alternative forms and/or hybrid use of sustainable energy such as LNG, solar panels or wind power.
  • Smart grid systems to track and manage peaks and lulls in energy consumption and achieve the lowest cost-combination of energy sources for peak operation levels.
  • Multi-purpose sensors and IoT to track and detect leakages of utilities in our infrastructures.
  • Recover, reuse and recycle materials, consumables and utilities.
  • Apps to reduce wastage and promote recycling among individuals through social interaction and gamification.
